alert.note: Alert for Hartford (Connecticut) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued July 11 at 6:38AM EDT until further notice by NWS Boston
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Connecticut...Massachusetts... Connecticut River At Thompsonville affecting Hampden and Hartford Counties. Connecticut River ABOVE Holyoke Dam affecting Hampden County. Connecticut River At Northampton affecting Hampden and Hampshire Counties. Connecticut River At Montague affecting Franklin and Hampshire Counties. Connecticut River Below Holyoke affecting Hampden County. Connecticut River At Hartford affecting Hartford and Middlesex Counties. Connecticut River At Middle Haddam affecting Middlesex County. Farmington River At Simsbury affecting Hartford County. West Deerfield River AT West Deerfield affecting Franklin County. For the Connecticut River...including Holyoke, Middle Haddam, Hartford, Thompsonville, Montague, Holyoke Dam, Northampton... Moderate flooding is forecast. For the Deerfield River...including West Deerfield...Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE... * WHAT...Moderate flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Connecticut River at Thompsonville. * WHEN...Until further notice. * IMPACTS...At 17.0 feet, Flooding will become more widespread along the Connecticut River from the Massachusetts towns of Agawam and Longmeadow, through the northern Connecticut towns of Suffield and Enfield. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 5:30 AM EDT Tuesday the stage was 14.8 feet. - Bankfull stage is 5.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage this morning to a crest of 17.2 feet just after midnight tonight. It will then fall below flood stage late tomorrow evening. - Flood stage is 15.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 17.2 feet on 10/10/2005. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued this afternoon at 315 PM EDT.
